quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we discuss why the product management field is so often disliked and what you can do to avoid becoming a product manager people don't want on their team.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical focus on diagnosing why PMs are disliked and concrete behaviors to avoid becoming a low-trust teammate.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We spend a lot of time on coaching, how to get better at coaching your reports, how to get better coaching from your manager, and some really clever tactics for building trust with leaders within your company.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Points to actionable skill-building around coaching up/down and specific trust-building tactics with leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Also, Christian shares his one favorite go-to method, out of all of the discovery methods out there, for figuring out what to build.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Teases a concrete, repeatable discovery methodology selection—useful for practitioners overwhelmed by many options.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Instead of dreaming up big ideas, talking to customers and crafting a strategy, you're drowning and spreadsheets and roadmap updates, and you're spending your days basically putting out fires.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Memorably captures a common anti-pattern in PM work that practitioners can recognize and work to correct.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Create and share custom product roadmaps with any stakeholder in seconds.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific, time-based claim about stakeholder communication speed that implies a workflow improvement target.

quotes.text: Great products are built by great teams, not just engineers.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Jira Product Discovery)
quotes.context: A memorable principle reinforcing cross-functional ownership as a core product-building model.

quotes.topic_title: Why product managers are often disliked
quotes.text: I think most people don't like product managers often because they haven't experienced good product managers.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: Reframes PM dislike as an experience/competence gap rather than an inherent problem with the role.

quotes.topic_title: Why product managers are often disliked
quotes.text: The core of product management is competency-based, meaning there is someone in an organization that represents the customer the best, that has a deep knowledge of the customers and your users, that has a deep knowledge of your data, your industry, your business and the product itself.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: Defines a clear competency model for what earns PMs trust: customer, data, industry, business, and product depth.

quotes.topic_title: Why product managers are often disliked
quotes.text: So one, I don't really think it's... I often say it's not the hate for product management, it's a hate for the understanding of what they have experienced in product management, which are people that are not able to deliver results that help them meet the outcomes they want.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: Connects PM sentiment directly to outcome delivery, making “results” the practical bar for credibility.

quotes.topic_title: Why product managers are often disliked
quotes.text: So if I were advising product managers, I often say, look, when we see sales or executive driven product management where we see these alternatives to product management, it's not a cultural knock or a leadership knock, it's really on the individual and the discipline has to elevate itself to a place that it earns the right to make a decision on what we do.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: treat sales/executive-driven roadmaps as a signal to raise PM competence and earn decision rights.

quotes.topic_title: How PMs earn trust and credibility
quotes.text: I've only seen great product managers come out of two places. One, either a series of massive failure in their career or experiences that have been bad or from learning from great product leaders.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: A contrarian take on where PM excellence actually comes from—hard-earned failure or direct apprenticeship under strong leaders.

quotes.topic_title: How PMs earn trust and credibility
quotes.text: So there is this period of humility that I challenge all product managers to have, this period of learning, recognizing what you do not know.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: A practical mindset shift: credibility starts with explicitly acknowledging gaps and committing to deliberate learning.

quotes.topic_title: How PMs earn trust and credibility
quotes.text: You're going to find the loudest, most influential person in your organization, the person that everybody knows, knows everything, is in every meeting and stuff, and you're going to ask them to teach you.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: A concrete tactic for accelerating business context and credibility by learning directly from the organization’s key influencer.

quotes.topic_title: How PMs earn trust and credibility
quotes.text: Now, what you're doing is you're extending that person's trust to yourself.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: “borrow” trust via association and apprenticeship before you’ve earned it independently.

quotes.topic_title: How PMs earn trust and credibility
quotes.text: After you've done that, you have to keep doing discovery because what's going to be different now is that person knows they've taught you everything that they know, but everybody now sees you learning every single day.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: An actionable operating system: continuous discovery builds visible competence over time, which converts into trust.

quotes.topic_title: SVPG PM fundamentals: four product risks
quotes.text:
And every time you solve a problem, there's inherent risk involved. There's the risk of will people buy this or will they choose it or will they choose to use it, which is all a value type of risk. There's the risk of can they use it, which is a usability type of risk. The risk that we can build it to have the skills to build it or the time to build this, that's a feasibility risk.

And the risk of it working for our business, which is a viability risk.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: A clear, actionable taxonomy of the four core product risks (value, usability, feasibility, viability) that teams can use to structure discovery and decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: SVPG PM fundamentals: four product risks
quotes.text: I cannot call out the product manager's competency. It's really to try to drive the first and the last one, which is value and viability. A solution worth building, something people will buy, choose or use, and one that works for our business, which is at the core of what product teams do, solve a problem in a way customers will love and a way that works for our business.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: Defines PM excellence as owning value and viability outcomes—not just shipping—while partnering with design/engineering on the rest.

quotes.topic_title: SVPG PM fundamentals: four product risks
quotes.text: Nobody wants to work on something nobody wanted in the first place and your job is to ensure that we are working on something people want in the first place.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: A blunt accountability standard for PMs: prevent wasted effort by validating demand before building.

quotes.topic_title: SVPG PM fundamentals: four product risks
quotes.text: I try to explain to people that the real essence of this job is that you wake up on behalf of someone else to solve a problem for them.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that centers product work on customer advocacy and problem-solving rather than outputs.

quotes.topic_title: SVPG PM fundamentals: four product risks
quotes.text: If it's not fun, you're probably not doing it right. If it's not hard, you're probably also not doing it right.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: A counterintuitive barometer for product work: the right problems are both challenging and intrinsically motivating.

quotes.topic_title: Why value risk is most often missed
quotes.text: Oh my goodness, value. Value is probably, it is the most important and the most overlooked.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: Highlights value risk as the primary failure mode for PMs and the area that deserves disproportionate attention.

quotes.topic_title: Why value risk is most often missed
quotes.text: Teams are often given roadmaps of projects and features to go build and deliver. If that's the case, you actually really don't need a product manager because they're going to assume value.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: A sharp critique of project/roadmap-driven operating models that implicitly skip validating whether the work is worth doing.

quotes.topic_title: Why value risk is most often missed
quotes.text: And it's not that they're more special in solving the problem that the designer or the engineer, but they're answering a question that determines if we should be working on this in the first place.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: Defines the PM’s core leadership role as deciding whether the team should invest effort at all—an explicit value-risk gate.

quotes.topic_title: Why value risk is most often missed
quotes.text: We often see bad patterns where companies will say, "Yes, we ran a test, with 300 users and they all scored it 84% or 90%. They love it."
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: Gives a concrete example of how teams misread usability/attitudinal testing as proof of value.

quotes.topic_title: Why value risk is most often missed
quotes.text: Well, just because somebody can use your product doesn't mean that they will buy it. Just because they can use it doesn't mean they will choose it. Just because they can use it doesn't mean that they will actually use it.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: A memorable mental model separating usability from value by tying value to buying, choosing, and sustained usage behaviors.

quotes.topic_title: Reference customers as the best discovery method
quotes.text: The holy grail of product walk is really a reference customer. This is somebody that has used your solution or your product, loves it enough to tell people about it.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: Defines the core discovery target—creating customers who will actively advocate for the product.

quotes.topic_title: Reference customers as the best discovery method
quotes.text: The ultimate definition for me today of the love that somebody has for our product is they're willing to put their reputation on the line by telling people about it.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: Offers a concrete, high-bar metric for product value: reputational willingness to recommend.

quotes.topic_title: Reference customers as the best discovery method
quotes.text: If you truly, truly want to solve a problem, get out of your building, get out of the assumptions, get out of your opinions. Immerse yourself, find someone who has the problem, stick with them until you discover a solution for this problem.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: Actionable discovery method: immersive, end-to-end problem solving with real customers rather than abstract research.

quotes.topic_title: Reference customers as the best discovery method
quotes.text: The part of why I love this technique, the two biggest reasons I think, the first is if I cannot find a certain number of people that have this problem, my goodness, it might not be a problem, but solve it.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: A practical demand test: inability to find enough sufferers is a signal the problem may not be worth solving.

quotes.topic_title: Reference customers as the best discovery method
quotes.text: everybody knows my favorite technique is if we find a problem worth solving, we need to uncover a solution for B2B, I want six to eight references, for B2C, I want maybe 15 to 25 references as an indication that we've achieved product market fit.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: Provides specific numeric targets for reference customers as a proxy indicator of product-market fit.

quotes.topic_title: How many references signal product-market fit
quotes.text: Your advice is find six to eight in B2B space, 15 to 25 in B2C.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Gives concrete reference-customer thresholds practitioners can use to reduce the risk of building for outliers.

quotes.topic_title: How many references signal product-market fit
quotes.text: And the reason there's a number here is if you find just one or two, you never know, they might be just the one or two that have this really weird problem that no one else has.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Explains why small-sample validation is dangerous and why a minimum reference set is a practical safeguard.

quotes.topic_title: How many references signal product-market fit
quotes.text: My idea here is if you found a steakhouse with 25 5-star reviews, you are likely to adopt this.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: Uses a familiar consumer analogy to justify a specific social-proof threshold for B2C adoption.

quotes.topic_title: How many references signal product-market fit
quotes.text: So in every app I have ever put on the App Store, on the day I launch the app in the app store, they are 25 5-star reviews.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable launch criterion that operationalizes “don’t launch until you have proof of love.”

quotes.topic_title: How many references signal product-market fit
quotes.text: Sometimes I might need to work with 30 people or 50 people because the output is 25 reference customers.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: Highlights that recruiting and conversion to references is itself a signal, and sets an explicit target output metric.

quotes.topic_title: Defining “love”: reputation-on-the-line references
quotes.text: So product market fit is when you iterate it in this discovery, you've discovered and delivered something so meaningful that these customers that are your target customers, are willing to put their reputation on the line and be a reference. That's my indication.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: Defines a concrete, reputation-based test for product-market fit at the individual level (willingness to be a reference).

quotes.topic_title: Defining “love”: reputation-on-the-line references
quotes.text: Because if I say, "Lenny, go write me a review, a five-star review." You're like, "I don't know if I feel comfortable about." You say, "Why not?" You see, I'm really going to get deeper feedback because people will say or do anything just to avoid hurting our feelings or for us to get out of their face.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: Shows how asking for a public commitment surfaces more honest objections than polite verbal feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Defining “love”: reputation-on-the-line references
quotes.text: I only market exactly what customers tell me.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: A practical positioning rule: use customer language verbatim to avoid expectation mismatch and improve go-to-market clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Defining “love”: reputation-on-the-line references
quotes.text: But for me, the fact that you will not have a product failure because you have a natural pivot out, meaning if I can't find 25 people that love steak, why in the world am I building a steakhouse?
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: Provides a recruiting-based kill criterion: inability to find enough eager early adopters is a signal to stop or pivot early.

quotes.topic_title: Defining “love”: reputation-on-the-line references
quotes.text: Can you find people that have this problem and care enough about this problem that they're going to talk to you and spend time exploring this thing that doesn't exist yet.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights recruitment effort as a leading indicator of real demand before building the product.

quotes.topic_title: One solution for many: avoiding custom one-offs
quotes.text: Can you find people that have this problem and care enough about this problem that they're going to talk to you and spend time exploring this thing that doesn't exist yet.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical discovery test: recruiting willingness is a strong signal of real pain and motivation before you build.

quotes.topic_title: One solution for many: avoiding custom one-offs
quotes.text: And then I think another key part of this is it's one solution that solves many people's problems. And it can't be a bunch of different things for a bunch of different people.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A clear product principle: avoid fragmented solutions by ensuring a single core offering fits a broad set of users.

quotes.topic_title: One solution for many: avoiding custom one-offs
quotes.text: All 25 have to want the same thing. If one person's out, you just don't do it at all.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: A strict decision rule for avoiding one-off customization and keeping scope minimal and scalable.

quotes.topic_title: One solution for many: avoiding custom one-offs
quotes.text: And the reason that's powerful is because if I come to you and I say, "Hey, it's missing this feature." I say, "Well yeah, 25 people that look like you that are very happy without it."
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: A rebuttal tactic that uses reference customers to resist feature creep and reinforce confidence in the core solution.

quotes.topic_title: One solution for many: avoiding custom one-offs
quotes.text: So your references are super powerful in more than any company, in influencing consumers on what they should choose or not choose.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: A counterintuitive go-to-market insight: references don’t just validate—they actively shape what customers perceive they need.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: high-volume hiring product built manually
quotes.text: And my first question to him as a product guy is like, "Wow, would you give me a million dollars to solve this problem?"
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: A simple willingness-to-pay test to quickly validate urgency and value before investing in a solution.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: high-volume hiring product built manually
quotes.text: Now the first thing I have to do is to try to define the problem, identify problems. What really is the problem going on?
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: Emphasizes disciplined problem definition as the first step before jumping to solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: high-volume hiring product built manually
quotes.text: Now, all we're doing here is just validating that this is a real problem, like other people will have the problem.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: A clear articulation of early-stage validation: confirm the problem generalizes beyond the first customer.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: high-volume hiring product built manually
quotes.text: He said, "Look, I forgot to tell you. Folks in this industry don't even show up to interviews. We are McDonald's, we pay minimum wage. People will leave us for 25 more cents an hour. They will leave us for a job that is one block closer to their house or less than a mile closer to their home."
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: A counterintuitive constraint that changes the solution approach: reliability and proximity can matter more than brand or process.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: high-volume hiring product built manually
quotes.text: If you really want to solve this problem, playing the laws of averages, we probably need to send this man close to 200 people. We need to go bigger.
quotes.speaker: Christian Idiodi
quotes.context: A practical scaling heuristic: when funnel drop-off is structural, solve via volume and conversion math rather than small optimizations.
